bibl.title: Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.p: Sierra Leone District Yearly Report Henry Rider

Consular Agent Freeform the port of entry for the Colony of Sierra Leone West Africa, lies in 1842 N. and 13 14' /8. It is a place of some note and has been burned the metropolis oof this particular part of the coast. The port contains some six or seven thousand inhab -itants and the census taken before the late epidemic returns nearly forty thousand people in the colony. The exports of the place are ground nuts, hides, palm oil, camwood, , palm kernels, beeswax, ivory and native gold. Ground nuts and find their principal market in France and are almost wholy shipped in French bottoms, palm oil, palm kernels, and bees-wax, are also shipped to France but in smaller quantities. Palm-oil and hides are the principal exports to the United States, besides which small quantities of groundnut, camwood and ivory are occasionally shipped, these freight are confined to

to American vessels. England presents a market for all the exports of the colony in a quart- er or less degree. The imports are Tobacco in hogshead, rum, provisions, and a few dry goods, from the United States, dry goods and provisions of every description from England dry goods, mints, and liquors, from France. The port does not present a flourishing cena- -dition, on the contray a stranger is im- pressed with the streets are grass-grown with but little havel through them and there are dilapidated houses, and lots overrun with weeds to be met with at every step; the black population, with some exceptions, are very poor and inactive, preferring to remain about town earning perhaps enough for a single meal, to living in the village and cultiva- ting the land, which with a moderate amount of labor would remumerate them kandsomely; the exceptions are generally liberated Africans, who by strict economy and much shrewdness have accumalted money and are, with the few Europeans, the business men of the place, the apathy before spoken of horroer, is entirely

enitrely confined to apperance, for the commer- cial interests of the place are of considerable importance, the reverence have increased steadily for some years past a corresponding increase in the commerce of the colony, the a- mount of business done with United States is not inconsiderable as the following returns for 1859 wil show
Total of American importations $20,209.14.1 . " " 0/0 . exportations $50,202.17. The returns for 1860 I have not been able to obtain.
The commerce with France is much more important than that of the United States, and
